Mark Renton.Action: Maintains lead while running from two tough pursuers despite heavy stolen goods falling out of his jacket.
Stops and smiles at pursuers and shocked driver instead of running, potentially risking capture.
Lies motionless and drugged on the floor, seemingly incapacitated.
Lies back on the astroturf after being hit in the face by the ball, showing no aggression or retaliation.
Narrates a critical, bleak view of conventional life and society but does not express hostility toward others directly.
Chooses heroin despite knowing the consequences, indicating self-destructive behavior and possible withdrawal from social warmth.
Observes his friends preparing to shoot up but offers no judgment or interference.
Sitting with his family but not eating, seeming withdrawn as his parents criticize him
Standing up while others lie drugged up, possibly indicating some detachment or unwillingness to partake
Declares his intention to quit heroin and claims to use the 'Sick Boy method' successfully.
Acknowledges he will almost certainly have another hit despite claiming to quit, showing self-awareness about his addiction.
Meticulously prepares his flat for withdrawal with detailed provisions and planning.
Smiles despite discomfort after using opium suppositories.
Calls Mikey for help without hesitation despite their usual strained relationship.
Proactively obtains Valium from his mother to manage withdrawal and plans a careful detox setup with detailed supplies.
Makes persistent calls to Mikey to get drugs needed despite initial setbacks.
Uses opium suppositories as advised for slow release but immediately expresses disappointment about their effectiveness.
Shows awareness of heroin side effects (constipation) and notices body signals, indicating self-monitoring.
Falls to knees in pain in public, showing physical weakness and loss of control in withdrawal moment.
Endures physical discomfort and humiliation alone to retrieve suppositories, showing self-reliance but no social interaction or kindness.
Successfully retrieves suppositories from a disgusting toilet by creatively and persistently plunging his arm completely in.
Demonstrates determination and resourcefulness in adverse conditions.
Engages in casual conversation with Sick Boy, showing tolerance despite disinterest (does not pick up the book thrown at him).
Agrees to meet Sick Boy at the park, maintaining social connection after coming off drugs.
Accurately remembers film details when prompted by Sick Boy, showing some knowledge and quick recall.
Fails to pick up the film guide thrown to him by Sick Boy, showing disinterest or laziness in verifying facts.
Persistent in asking who wrote the film until finally given the correct answer, showing determination despite some gaps in knowledge.
Organizes to meet with Sick Boy, carrying items (cassette player and food) for their meeting, indicating preparation and forethought.
Expresses awareness of the difficulty of interacting sober with friends after addiction, demonstrating self-awareness and insight.
Feels unable to tolerate Sick Boy's competitive and undermining behavior as Sick Boy tries to show off his own success in quitting junk.
Engages in a somewhat dismissive and sarcastic verbal exchange with Sick Boy, questioning and downplaying his opinions.
Engages in a critical conversation demonstrating awareness and skepticism towards Sick Boy's theory, challenging and questioning his points.
Feels overwhelmed by seeing his friends and himself reflected in their struggles, indicating emotional difficulty coping with situation.
Wishes Spud good luck and advises him carefully on his job interview strategy, showing concern for his friend's success.
Offers Spud amphetamine to help him cope with nerves during the job interview.
Engages in cynical banter and violent behavior with Sick Boy (shooting the dog), showing a lack of empathy.
Successfully shoots the dog's owner indirectly by shooting the dog, showing skill and confidence with a gun.
Explains to Spud how to handle job interviews strategically, showing understanding and intelligence.
Prepares to give Spud amphetamine to help with nerves at a job interview, showing practical awareness and an unconventional but pragmatic approach.
Leaves the packet of amphetamine in Spud's hand for him to try.
Speaks fondly and sincerely about his school days and experiences.
Openly admits to his heroin addiction and gaps in his employment during the job interview.
Engages confidently and articulately in a job interview, recalling school motto and speaking with apparent sincerity.
Openly admits to extensive heroin addiction and criminal behavior during job interview, risking opportunity.
Expresses pride in Spud after his interview despite Spud's self-admitted flaws.
Casually refers to Spud's failure with crude language but in a seemingly affectionate tone.
Recognizes and praises Spud's good performance in the interview and shows pride in his friend.
Understands social nuances, referencing Spud's success with a mix of humor and support.
No direct demonstration of skill or intelligence in this excerpt beyond social commentary and internal observations.
Squares up casually to a threatening individual, showing readiness and confidence, effectively taking control of the situation.
Relies on Tommy's honesty to discern the truth behind Begbie's story, exhibiting a cautious and intelligent approach to information.
Passively listens to Begbie's exaggerated story without immediate challenge, potentially indicating a lack of assertiveness or critical engagement.
Observes Tommy lifting weights and watches the pool game scenario attentively, demonstrating awareness of social dynamics.
Passively listens and does not intervene in Begbie's escalating aggression despite recognizing the tension.
Describes Begbie as a mate despite his violent behavior, tries to remain detached to avoid involvement.
Holds up 100 Great Goals and asks to borrow it, showing familiarity with football culture and social currency.
Watches events involving Begbie with a detached, knowing attitude, commenting insightfully on Begbie's personality.
Sits dispassionately watching a homemade soft-porn video, showing emotional detachment but no active engagement or response.
Notices Spud and Tommy with their partners but remains distant, standing apart among lone nerds.
Observes and reflects cynically on successful men segregating themselves from failures, showing social alienation and judgment.
Wades onto the dance floor seeking connection, indicating desire for social interaction despite repeated rejection.
Observes social dynamics and recognizes his own social and sexual failures compared to others.
Attempts to engage women on the dance floor but fails repeatedly as they turn away or are already spoken for.
Mentally assesses his post-heroin sexual frustration and its impact on his behavior.
Compliments Diane sincerely and cautiously expresses interest without pressuring her.
Awkwardly attempts to engage Diane and admits nervousness, showing vulnerability.
Approaches Diane politely and acknowledges her capable behavior, showing social awareness and confidence.
Hesitates and stammers when Diane questions his approach, revealing social awkwardness.
Attempts to engage Diane without pressure, suggesting cautious confidence.
Leaves conversation abruptly with an excuse as Diane gets into the taxi, indicating missed opportunity or inability to maintain composure.
Climaxes with Diane and makes a friendly, nostalgic comment referencing a shared cultural moment.
Insists on staying despite Diane telling him to leave and being firm about it.
Peeks out from under blanket but stays withdrawn, avoiding interaction with normal morning sounds.
Responds politely to Diane’s flatmates, engages in light conversation, and acknowledges connection with Diane.
Describes himself as 'more of a friend of a friend' rather than a close friend, showing modesty and honesty.
Enters Diane's home confidently, introduces himself politely, makes small talk with her flatmates, follows their gaze to notice Diane in school uniform, showing situational awareness.
Walks away from Diane when she asks to see him again, refusing.
Turns back after Diane threatens to tell police, then leaves again with a smile from Diane.
Expresses dislike of being Scottish when encouraged to appreciate it
Makes a 'healthy, informed, democratic decision' to get back on drugs quickly, indicating an awareness and calculated acceptance of consequences.
Hands over money and begins cooking up drugs competently, acknowledging that drug use and procurement is a 'full-time business' and not as easy as it seems.
Engages in shoplifting alongside others, demonstrating some skill in theft as they are stuffing objects into shirts and pockets.
Runs from Store Detectives with Spud, managing to evade capture, showing quick thinking and physical capability.
Lies back narcotized multiple times, indicating passivity and loss of agency due to drug influence.

Expresses strong negative views on Scottish identity and self, but does not take positive action to change situation, showing a combination of intelligence and self-awareness but also a kind of nihilism or defeatism.
Trawls through parents' drawers to find cash/jewelry for drug money.
Lies back vacantly, showing little awareness or engagement when Tommy confides about his breakup.
With Spud, breaks into hospital ward and steals TV in front of elderly patients.
Huddles away from Tommy when Tommy wants to try drugs, showing reluctance to encourage harm.
Calmly disables car alarm and steals battery and stereo without alarming others.
Participates in theft and drug-related activities involving vulnerable groups (cancer victims, alcoholics, old age pensioners, AIDS patients, epileptics, bored housewives).
Calmly disarms a car alarm using wire cutters and a spanner to steal the battery and stereo.
Organizes or participates in thefts and drug deals showing practical knowledge and planning.
Engages in illegal and immoral activities such as stealing from vulnerable people and drug use.
Steals a prescription pad off the GP's desk while the GP is distracted.
Takes his share of the money from a quick theft and agrees to avoid heroin this time.
Involved in planning and executing a theft (stealing the American's jacket/passport), showing coordination with the group.
Passively lies back while others throw a ball at his head repeatedly without reacting.
Wishes he could say something sympathetic and human to Allison after her baby's death.
Cooks drugs to help Allison get a hit to take away her pain after the baby's death.
Wishes he could think of something sympathetic or human to say but remains silent.
Begins scrambling around to 'cook up' drugs when Allison demands a hit, meeting immediate practical need.
Internally processes the tragic situation with some reflection and awareness of others' pain.
Steals items alongside friends without hesitation; lets stolen goods fall revealing his theft; stolen goods cause others to snigger at him.
Looks at Diane after being caught stealing, showing some hesitation or shame.
Smiles and waits to be caught by the detective, accepting consequences calmly rather than resisting or fleeing selfishly.
Thanks the sheriff sincerely and expresses hope to conquer his addiction with God's help.
Looks at Spud in court, showing concern or connection.
Apologizes sincerely to Spud's mother, showing remorse and empathy.
Expresses feeling alone and alienated despite being surrounded by family and mates, indicating internal sensitivity.
Slips away silently when Begbie gets drinks in, avoiding confrontation or group interaction.
Wishes he had gone down instead of Spud, showing guilt but also self-centeredness in perspective.
Allows Swanney to care for him and accept help arranging transport despite his vulnerable state.
Shows no direct friendly or sincere interaction with Swanney beyond transactions; primarily focused on drug use.
Produces twenty pounds when his credit limit is reached, indicating awareness and ability to handle payment despite prior debt.
Lies back silently and injects himself with drugs, showing habitual and unreflective drug use rather than proactive or skillful behavior.
Passively allows Swanney to drag him into a taxi instead of seeking help or asserting control over his situation.
Lies passively on the pavement and in hospital, showing no hostility or bitterness toward others despite harsh treatment.
Allows himself to be handled roughly and dumped repeatedly without complaint.
Lies unconscious and is passively moved by others, showing no control or active response during hospitalization.
No indication of skillful or confident behavior; completely dependent on hospital staff and family.
Expresses appreciation to his mother despite his craving and illness, acknowledges their help.
Asks for a drug score to ease withdrawal pain, showing self-interest and difficulty in abstaining.
Requests to go back to the clinic or get some medication to ease withdrawal symptoms.
Lies to his parents about past drug use and treatment outcomes.
Acknowledges and appreciates his parents' efforts to help and keep him safe.
Tears Baby Dawn off his face and throws her into a corner.
Tears the baby crawling on the ceiling off his face and throws it into a corner, showing quick physical reaction and assertiveness.
Looks around at surreal and disturbing hallucinations without losing composure, suggesting mental resilience.
Appears passive during interactions, such as allowing Parents to wash him and being told there is something he needs to do, indicating some level of submission or lack of control.
Spends time calmly with his mother and father, allowing them to share in the moment of relief and joy after medical test results.
At the social club, instead of engaging in the game with others, he observes people and leaves his drink untouched.
Sincerely apologizes to Tommy for testing positive.
Shares his bingo winnings with Tommy to help him out.
Engages casually and sympathetically with Tommy despite their bleak circumstances.
Internally acknowledges the harshness of their situation with some empathy.
Sits with Swanney in hospital and listens silently without mocking or dismissing him.
Encourages Swanney's plans by responding positively and showing interest.
Engages in casual conversation with Sick Boy, showing camaraderie despite grim topics.
Asks Sick Boy about visiting Tommy and shows concern about his illness.
Tuts when Sick Boy stiffens and avoids his gaze, indicating disappointment.
Rejects Sick Boy's drug dealing plan with a blunt 'Fuck you.'
Answers door and confirms he is clean when Diane asks, showing some openness.
Sitting alone, calmly making a joint and reading a book, displaying focus and a measure of self-awareness.
Responds sarcastically or dismissively to Sick Boy's drug dealing ambitions and attitudes.
Shows awareness of others' situations (Tommy's infection) and challenges Sick Boy's indifferent attitude.
Answers door cautiously and briefly (to Diane), implying guardedness but not clear competence or incompetence.
Firmly assures Diane he is clean and resists her suggestion to do hash, emphasizing honesty.
Tells Diane she is too young, which could be seen as protective or dismissive.
Engages in friendly banter with Diane about Iggy Pop and music, showing openness and connection.
Remains contemplative and open to Diane's advice about change, acknowledging he needs to find something new.
Affirms he is clean and denies using hash despite the smell, showing self-control and honesty.
Looks around the empty passageway before responding, indicating caution and awareness of surroundings.
Corrects Diane's misunderstanding about Iggy Pop, showing knowledge and attentiveness.
Acknowledges internally the need to change and find something new, showing self-reflection and planning.
Avoids confrontation or argument when Diane challenges him, demonstrating composure.
Holds door open and ushers a couple into a flat he is showing.
Keeps to himself, does not engage with others, states he did not miss the guys.
Reads letter alone, eats pot noodle quietly, shows introspective behavior.
Wears a shirt and tie, takes a telephone call professionally, reads information from a paper confidently.
Conducts a flat viewing, describes the property and its faults clearly and factually while interacting with potential tenants.
Reflects on his new lifestyle with a degree of acceptance and detachment, showing awareness of the environment and his own adaptation.
Re-examines Diane's letter with concern before opening door to Begbie
Sits calmly as Begbie points a gun at his head without showing panic or aggression
Re-examines Diane's letter carefully when buzzed at the door.
Opens door hesitantly and calmly to Begbie despite potential danger.
Sits on bed facing Begbie with gun pointed at him without panicking.
Does not attempt to escalate or resolve the conflict with Begbie aggressively or impulsively.
Lets Begbie settle in quickly, tolerates his antisocial behavior without complaint.
Responds minimally when Begbie demands cigarettes, closes door and walks away.
Acknowledges Begbie’s difficult nature but still calls him a mate.
Asks Begbie to put a bet on himself rather than helping more actively.
Pauses at the door, listens to Begbie, and calmly closes the door rather than engaging in conflict.
Closes the door again after dealing with Begbie's cigarette demand without argument.
Lies awake annoyed by Begbie's snoring but accepts the situation as dealing with a difficult friend.
Sits reading a book calmly beside Begbie who is indulging in self-destructive behavior.
Passively allows Begbie's erratic and excessive behavior (cigarettes and alcohol) to continue without intervention.
Refuses to assist Begbie with a bet, suggesting Begbie handle things himself despite Begbie's fugitive status.
Reflects humorously and critically on social changes and Begbie's nature while remaining detached at a party.
Places a calculated bet at Kempton Park, wins at 16 to 1, and uses the winnings wisely for celebration.
Observes the club scene and cultural changes insightfully, showing awareness and thoughtful reflection.
Sits passively at the party drinking beer while others actively engage and dance.
Sits on the floor watching Begbie, showing a non-aggressive, calm demeanor despite tension.
Makes a lighthearted comment about Begbie's situation ('Let's face it, it could have been wonderful').
Allows Begbie to threaten and intimidate him without retaliating or escalating the conflict.
Narrates about Sick Boy’s schemes with a tone that suggests tolerance or mild criticism but no hostility.
Mentions his own tiredness and haggard state at work, implying a resigned or isolated attitude.
Expresses anger when Sick Boy steals his television, refuses to eat, reclaims his passport to prevent further betrayal.
Throws Sick Boy and Begbie out of his flat by giving them the keys and leaving, ending their freeloading presence.
Content to be alone in a messy bedsit, showing detachment but no active hostility.
Drops his passport into an envelope and locks it in a left luggage locker to prevent Sick Boy and Begbie from stealing it.
Shows Sick Boy and Begbie the London flat, gives them the keys, and leaves them there.
Leaves his fish supper untouched while Sick Boy takes it without permission.
Attends Tommy's funeral with friends and family, respects the moment.
Dismisses Lizzy's feelings about the kitten harshly with cynical remark.
Reflects on Tommy's tragic state with evident concern and sadness.
Looks around the stripped, empty bedsit one last time before closing the door as he leaves.
Comments with some uncertainty on Tommy's illness ('Eh? How's that?'), showing lack of medical knowledge.
Asks questions to understand what toxoplasmosis is, showing curiosity and willingness to learn.
Passively listens to others recount tragic events without taking constructive action or showing initiative to help.
Refuses to lend money for a drug deal despite friends' pressure after a recent funeral.
Questions friends about the drug deal with some incredulity and concern about consequences.
Refuses to lend two thousand pounds despite pressure and being aware of friends' risky plan.
Questions the wisdom of buying four kilos of drugs implicating a potentially huge risk.
Shows no immediate emotional reaction at Tommy's funeral, instead focusing on the drug deal, which may indicate emotional detachment but also practical focus.
Suggests a drug deal involving friends with a plan where everyone profits, tries to meet up with Diane despite her having a boyfriend.
Engages in light teasing with Diane, both laugh together.
Injects heroin himself so others in the group don't have to try it first, showing self-sacrifice or responsibility.
Rolls up his sleeve and injects heroin himself when others refuse.
Walks past a beggar who lost his leg for the country without interaction or assistance.
Mentally reflects on Begbie's fear and grudgingly understands his behaviour.
Observes and internally analyzes the negotiation process, recognizing their amateur status and the risks involved.
Engages in a risky drug deal knowing they are perceived as inexperienced small-time dealers.
Expresses a brief feeling of camaraderie and friendship after the deal, noting it 'felt really great, like we were all in it together, like friends'
Jokes with Spud about buying an island, showing a playful and friendly attitude
Offers to buy the next round of drinks ('It's your round Franco') contributing to group camaraderie
Shows distrust of Sick Boy, telling Begbie 'The moment you turn your back, we're out that door,' implying a plan to steal the money
Negotiates a deal resulting in sixteen thousand pounds, feeling momentarily positive about group unity.
Suggests to immediately leave with the money as soon as Sick Boy turns his back, indicating awareness and quick thinking.
Engages in casual banter and orders drinks to maintain social cover.
Tells Begbie to cool down and acknowledges the man's apology.
Sits still and avoids looking at the violent fight Begbie starts.
Sits still, avoids involvement in Begbie's violent fight, keeps focus on the bag of money and fiddles with it.
Uncertain about escaping with the money, says 'I don't know. What do you think?', showing hesitation.
Attempts to calm Begbie down by saying 'Cool down, Franco. The guy's sorry.'
Does not intervene to stop Begbie from instigating or escalating violence despite clear signs it will lead to a fight.
Complies nervously with Begbie's demands to bring a cigarette and the bag, despite personal fear and discomfort.
Carefully lifts Begbie's arm so he can take the bag without waking him, showing consideration.
Hands a small wad of cash to Spud quietly and without fuss, indicating trustworthiness and support.
Feels sorry for Spud, acknowledging he never hurt anybody despite betraying the group.
Admits to having ripped off his friends, calling himself a bad person.
Chooses to betray his friends for personal gain (stealing passports and money).
Expresses intention to change and lead a morally better life.
Rips off his friends by stealing their money and passport, showing planning and execution of the theft.
Justifies the betrayal with rationalizations to himself, showing some self-awareness but also moral weakness.
Decides to 'clean up and move on' to a conventional life, demonstrating intention and resolve to change.
Characterizes himself as a 'bad person' but claims this will change without demonstrating concrete steps or confidence in his ability to do so.
